subject: Fitch Affirms Austria at 'AA+'; Outlook Positive
RANsquawk US Market Wrap - Havens in demand as Trump threatens Mexico tariffs
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. US MARKET WRAP - 31 MAY 2019: Havens in demand as Trump threatens Mexico tariffs

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equites down, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude down.

* REAR VIEW: Trump threatens tariffs on Mexico over immigration, China to retaliate against US firms, US to postpone Iranian petrochemical sanctions, confusion over Italy’s reply to EC letter, US PCE inline, Chicago PMI slightly better, Michigan slightly lower, Canada monthly GDP firm.

* NEXT WEEK: MON: Swiss CPI, Turkish CPI, EZ, UK and US mfg PMI, US ISM mfg, Construction Spending, NZ Trade. TUE: RBA Rate Decision, UK Construction PMI, EZ CPI & Unemployment, US Factory Orders, Aus GDP. WED: EZ, UK and US services PMI, EZ PPI & Retail Sales, US ADP Employment, US ISM non-mfg, Polish Rate Decision, Aus Trade. THU: German Factory Orders, RBI and ECB rate decisions, EZ Employment and GDP (F), US Challenger, Trade, Unit Labor Costs, Nonfarm Productivity, Canadian Trade. FRI: Swiss Unemployment, German and French Trade, German Industrial Production, US and Canadian Labor Market Reports, US Wholesales Inventories. To download RANsquawk week ahead preview, please click here.

 

* MEXICO: US President Trump said the US will on 10th June impose a 5% tariff on all goods coming into the country from Mexico, until such time as illegal migrants coming through Mexico into the US stop. The rate would be gradually extendable by 5% per month, up to 25% by 1st October. White House officials also attempted to de-link the new measures against Mexico from the USMCA, stating that the moves were not part of the trade dispute, adding that the US has seen enough cooperation from Mexico such that tariffs may not even take effect. Mexico President Lopez Obrador's response was more circumspect, saying Mexico will not respond to any US provocations, and will be prudent with the US; he added that disputes must be resolved by dialogue, not through coercive measures. AMLO also said that he does not wish to seek WTO involvement at this stage, though he later said US trade issue would not change Mexico's migration policy. Trump, meanwhile, continued Twitter “diplomacy,” bemoaning the trade deficit with Mexico, and some analysts noted that although the US official position was that the latest round of measures was about immigration, Trump's tweet seems to suggest that there is a trade element to it. Meanwhile, Mexico said it will continue with USMCA ratification. Reports later emerged indicating that US Trade Representative Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Mnuchin were said to have opposed new Mexican tariffs, arguing that it could harm USMCA.

* US/CHINA TRADE: There have been further reports that China has made plans to restrict exports of rare earths to the US, and the measures can be implemented as soon as the government decides to go ahead. A former Chinese Vice Foreign Minister also said China had more countermeasures, including on rare earths, as well as software, and measures targeting US industrial giant Boeing (BA). Later, the Global Times editor later said that, based on his understanding, China will take major retaliatory measures against the US' placing Huawei and other Chinese companies on Entity List, adding that Beijing would not wait passively, and more countermeasures would follow. He later said that he thinks only those foreign co's who have cut off supply chains in China will be put on the China entity list. Reports later confirmed that China tariffs on US imports will take effect at 00:00 local time, June 1st. On a more positive note, former PBOC Governor Dai believes there will be good news from China-US trade talks at the G20, although the process will be difficult. 

* GEOPOLITCAL: Following original US sanctions on Iranian crude, the Treasury was due to implement new sanctions on Iran’s second largest export, Petrochemicals, in mid-May but is now delaying that decision due to the desire to deescalate tensions between Washington and Tehran. On a similar note, WSJ reported overnight that the Trump administration said that it would continue to let Iranian crude importers (e.g. China and India), who were previously granted sanction waivers, continue importing to the cap they had been granted; previously nations were likely to be hesitant of exporting to their caps due to the escalation of tensions between US and Iran. Later on Friday, the quarterly IAEA report showed that Iran currently remains within the nuclear deal’s key limits in regard to uranium enrichment levels; this comes as Iran makes efforts to remain within the deal to maintain favourable relations with European trading partners.

* CHINA PMI: Overnight, official data showed its manufacturing PMI falling into contraction (at 49.4, down from 50.1, missing expectations of 49.9), suggesting that the Chinese economy is yet to bottom-out. New orders drove the downside in the headline, and export orders dropped sharply, suggesting that US trade measures on China is impacting foreign demand. The non-manufacturing PMI was steady at 54.3, while the composite measure fell by 0.1pts to 53.3.

* ITALY: Italy's 5-Star Movement came out favour of League's proposal to finance the flat tax measure by raising the budget deficit, triggering a weakening in BTPs. Reports subsequently emerged claiming that Italy had replied to the EU’s recent letter (regarding the country’s finances) saying it sees lower borrowing costs and will condition its flat tax on deficit targets. Italy Treasury quickly rubbished these reports, calling the reports inaccurate. Italy Deputy PM Di Maio later said he was not consulted over the letter to the EU over the budget and wants a government meeting before it is sent, which a government spokesperson said would be sent later today.

* BREXIT: A YouGov survey has seen surging support for the Lib Dems (historically, the UK's 'third' party), which overtook the Brexit party; Labour and Conservatives are now joint-third in the poll. Some desks have argued that if the wind continues to blow in this direction, it could result in a re-evaluation of potential risks of a second referendum.

* US CORE PCE: Core PCE Y/Y was 1.6%, rising from a revised down 1.5%. Although some Fed policymakers have warned that a inflation rate at these levels would call for aggressive arguments to loosen policy, Wells Fargo does not believe this while change the dial for the Fed: "If we take the monthly increase in the PCE deflator out to two decimal places, the increase was 0.25%; that is the biggest increase since October 2017, and the second largest in over a decade. So is inflation getting ready to take off and compel the Fed to change its signalling toward a return to eventual rate increases? Probably not," Wells says. While the bank notes that one month does not make a trend, the data might also be seen as a vindication for Chair Powell’s transitory view on the recent soft patch in inflation. "At 1.5%, the PCE deflator is still well below the Fed’s 2.0% target, and it bears keeping in mind that all the figures in today’s report reflect what was going on in April, before the recent escalation in the trade war."

* US PERSONAL INCOME AND SPENDING: Personal income and spending came in above expectations. Capital Economics says "even though real consumption was unchanged in April, consumption growth is still on track to rise by around 3% annualised in the Q2 overall," but "with the incoming survey evidence suggesting economic growth is faltering and the core PCE deflator running well below the Fed’s 2% target, the resilience of the consumer sector will not stop the Fed from cutting interest rates later this year," the consultancy argues. Real consumption stalled in April, following an upwardly revised 0.9% increase in March, but "that was a little better than we had anticipated given the already-reported decline in manufacturers' auto sales and the unusually mild weather which depressed demand for utilities," CapEco says. "Assuming modest gains in May and June, that suggests real consumption growth will come in at 3.0% annualised in the second quarter, up from 1.3% in the first."

* US UNI OF MICHIGAN SENTIMENT: The final May Michigan sentiment headline was revised lower to 100, missing expectations of 101.5. One-year inflation ticked up to 2.9% (highest since Oct) from 2.8%, while 5-10-year expectations were unchanged at 2.6%. Goldman Sachs says the headline fall may reflect the stock market declines, as well as heightened trade tensions.

* US CHICAGO PMI: May saw a rise to 54.2 from 52.6, beating the 54.0 consensus view. "The increase in the index is welcome but it remains depressed; in the first quarter, it averaged 59.8, but the troubles at Boeing -- based in the city -- and the trade war presumably are hurting, and the prospect of a deeper, longer dispute with China and now with Mexico too cannot be good for industrial sentiment," Pantheon Macroeconomics says. "More immediately, though, the uptick in the Chicago PMI, alongside May gains in the Philly Fed, Empire State and Richmond Fed surveys, points to a modest increase in Monday’s national ISM manufacturing index."

* CANADA GDP: March GDP rose above expectations (0.5% M/M vs 0.3% cons; 0.4% Q/Q annualised vs cons 0.7%), with the large drag from exports offsetting a rebound in domestic demand, which TD Securities says reflects stronger consumption and business investment. Q2 GDP tracking is now around 2%, according to TD's model, above the BOC's 1.3% estimate. "Solid details for Q1 and a strong handoff should underscore that domestic economic conditions will not warrant cuts in 2019, but the recent increase in global trade tensions could give a cautious tone to BOC communications."

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED +22 TICKS AT 126-12: This week has seen US 5yr yields fell to sub-2%, the 3m/10yr spread moved further into inversion (resulting in more commentary about the risks of recession over a 12-24 month horizon), and some data surprised to the downside, seeing the market price in three Fed rate cuts by the end of 2020. The fixed income bid was also supported by a slide in equities, although month-end models had suggest positive inflows into stocks. And the latest US measures against Mexico have added to Treasury upside as we close out the week; With 2s, 5s sub-2%, 7s are a couple of basis points away. Bund yields fell in sympathy, seeing German 10yr yields flirt with fresh all-time lows. Comments from Clarida on Thursday and the aforementioned risk-off were underpinning the bid on Friday. At settlement, the curve had bull-flattened, though major curve spreads were steeper (notably the 2s20s widened 6bps, 2s10s +5bps, 5s30s +3bps, 2s5s +3bps).

* WTI (N9) FUTURES SETTLE $3.09 LOWER AT $53.50/BBL; BRENT (N9, EXPIRES) $2.38 LOWER AT $64.49: The crude complex continued its drift lower in the US session on Friday, spurred by the threat of US tariffs on Mexico. The announcement of plans to implement tariffs of 5% on June 10th saw equities dip which lead to a flight to safety. Analysts at Citi note that the tariffs “would presumably apply to the 617K BPD of crude oil the US imported from Mexico last week.” It is worth highlighting that July Brent contracts, in addition to June heating oil and June RBOB, are expiring this week, “Declining open interest and trading volumes on those instruments may be contributing to the volatility here,” Citi adds. WTI ends the week around the USD 53.5/bbl mark, a significant fall from the above USD 60 level just over a week ago. The fall has been primarily due to global demand concerns, with hopes of a quick resolution to the US-China trade deal faltering, seeing risk assets fall off. Participants will be paying close attention to the slew of tier one data being released next week across major economies to get a better perspective on the state of global growth. A saving grace for bulls could also arise from geopolitics, where Iran-US tensions have been out of focus in recent sessions. Any news of a move towards conflict between members in the Middle-East could provide fresh bidding to the oil benchmarks as participants reassess oil supply. Baker Hughes weekly rig count showed US oil rigs +3 at 800, natgas rigs -2 at 184, total US rigs +1 at 984.

* S&P 500 -1.3% AT 2752, NASDAQ-100 -1.6% AT 7128, DOW JONES  -1.4% AT 24815; SECTORS: S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary  -1.4%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples  -1.4%, S&P 500 Energy  -1.6%, S&P 500 Financials  -1.5%, S&P 500 Health Care  -0.8%, S&P 500 Industrials  -1.5%, S&P 500 Information Technology  -1.6%, S&P 500 Materials  -1.2%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services  -2.1%, S&P 500 Utilities  0.4%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: US automakers, including Ford (F) and General Motors (GM), were under pressure after US President Trump said he would impose 5% tariffs on Mexican imports. Later Moody's said the new US tariffs on Mexico would be credit negative for the US auto sector which relies heavily on imports from Mexico. Constellations Brands (STZ), owner of Corona beer, was also hit by the news. Energy names, including ExxonMobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhilips (COP), shrugged off news that the US was to postpone petrochemical sanctions on Iran, in an apparent attempt to de-escalate tensions between the two nations, and instead followed the crude complex lower as risk sentiment soured. Tesla (TSLA) managed to outperform much of the tech/automaker sector on the day as news emerged that the firm was to lower the price of its Model S in China to spur demand. Costco (COST) lost ground despite the firm posting a beat on both top and bottom-line earnings expectations and Baird analyst Peter Benedict saying the co.’s bull thesis remains intact. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) sold off somewhat as news emerged that it had lost another talcum powder case, one of thousands and must pay a USD 300mln punitive award in New York. Gap (GPS) sunk after the co. reported poor earnings. Dell Technologies (DELL) opened lower after a revenue miss.

* FX DAILY WRAP: Safe havens outperformed after tensions between the US and Mexico escalated. JPY was the outperformer, with USDJPY breaking below 109.00 and closing in on 108.50. CHF was also firm, albeit underperforming the Yen, with the usual theories of SNB intervention capping gains, whilst XAU rose back above the psychological USD 1300 handle. Understandably, MXN sunk, with USDMXN moving as high as 19.80 (from 19.05 prior to the tweets). CAD was also hit as USMCA ratification hopes were dampened, whilst further downside in the crude complex did little to help (RUB and NOK also took a hit). Dollar weakness did allow some EMs to rise; BRL was a big winner after upbeat data (unemployment down, budget surplus up), whilst TRY was also firmer. AUD continues to be resilient in the face of risk-off, with some suggesting the extreme short positioning is limiting further Aussie downside for the time being. CNH weakened after former PBOC governor Zhou said 7.00 is not necessarily the USDCNH threshold. EUR was up, though did see jitters mid-session, after reports that Italy had written back to the EU, though these reports were subsequently dismissed which saw a recovery. DXY moved back below 98.00, with some desks attributing dovish remarks by Fed’s Clarida on Thursday, combined with more aggressive pricing of Fed rate cuts through 2020. GBP enjoyed another brief foray below the 1.2600 level this morning, amid a lack of fundamental drivers, but managed to reclaim the level as the dollar came off and EUR moved lower on political concerns. For full re-cap of this week’s FX action, please click here.

* MXN: UBS notes that positioning in MXN has been long, as high carry has favoured the MXN, but in its view, at c.19 the USDMXN was not pricing fundamental risks, let alone the threat from US tariffs, the bank argues. With that said, recent remarks by US and Mexican officials had been constructive, and the US has praised Mexico's efforts on stopping illegal immigration from Central America. Additionally, the recent removal of metals tariffs on Mexico and Canada served to improve the outlook for the approval of the USMCA in Congress. In terms of potential Banxico reaction, UBS says that "the knee-jerk reaction in the front-end of the TIIE curve would likely be to price-out rate cuts in 2019, but we would expect Banxico to use an increase in the NDF program before delivering an emergency hike to stop a disorderly depreciation in the peso." UBS had recently argued that despite weaker growth, "Banxico’s cautious stance regarding still high inflation and depreciation risks, would make us fade the pricing in the front-end of an earlier than currently expected start of a cutting cycle."

* RANSQUAWK CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY BRIEFING - 31ST MAY 2019: PREVIEWING Fed conference, ECB, RBA, RBI; Reviewing BOC, BOK. To download the report, please click here.

subject: FX WRAP: Safe havens dominate as US/Mexico trade tensions rise
content:
* FX DAILY WRAP: Safe havens outperformed after tensions between the US and Mexico escalated. JPY was the outperformer, with USDJPY breaking below 109.00 and closing in on 108.50. CHF was also firm, albeit underperforming the Yen, with the usual theories of SNB intervention capping gains, whilst XAU broke back above the psychological USD 1300 handle. Understandably, MXN sunk, with USDMXN moving as high as 19.80 (from 19.05 prior to the tweets). CAD was also hit as USMCA ratification hopes were dampened, whilst further downside in the crude complex did little to help (on which note, RUB and NOK also took a hit). However, dollar weakness allowed some EMs to appreciate; with BRL a big winner after upbeat data (unemployment down, budget surplus up), whilst TRY was also firmer. AUD was resilient in the face of risk off, with some suggesting the extreme short positioning is limiting further Aussie downside for the time being. CNH weakened after former PBoC governor Zhou said 7.00 is not necessarily the USD/CNH threshold, USDCNH popping higher to 6.9475 before retracing somewhat as the dollar came off. EUR was up, though did see jitters midsession, after reports that Italy had written back to the EU, though these reports were subsequently dismissed which did see a recovery. DXY moved back below 98.00, with some desks attributing dovish remarks by Fed’s Clarida on Thursday combined with more aggressive pricing of Fed rate cuts through 2020. GBP enjoyed another brief foray below the 1.2600 level this morning, amid a lack of fundamental drivers, but managed to reclaim the level as the dollar came off and EUR moved lower on political concerns.

* MXN: UBS notes that positioning in MXN has been long, as high carry has favoured the MXN, but in its view, at c.19 the USDMXN was not pricing fundamental risks, let alone the threat from US tariffs, the bank argues. With that said, recent remarks by US and Mexican officials had been constructive, and the US has praised Mexico's efforts on stopping illegal immigration from Central America. Additionally, the recent removal of metals tariffs on Mexico and Canada served to improve the outlook for the approval of the USMCA in Congress. In terms of potential Banxico reaction, UBS says that "the knee-jerk reaction in the front-end of the TIIE curve would likely be to price-out rate cuts in 2019, but we would expect Banxico to use an increase in the NDF program before delivering an emergency hike to stop a disorderly depreciation in the peso." UBS had recently argued that despite weaker growth, "Banxico’s cautious stance regarding still high inflation and depreciation risks, would make us fade the pricing in the front-end of an earlier than currently expected start of a cutting cycle."

* TRY: moved higher again. This is despite the continued backdrop of increasing tensions between Turkey and the US over the latter’s decision to press ahead with the purchase of Russia’s S-400 missile system (a Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesperson earlier dismissed reports that the Russian S-400 delivery will be delayed). Albeit, there were reports that the two nations were looking to set up “study groups” to mutually assess the pros and cons of the missile system, however the cloud of possible US sanctions on Turkey, which is already in a technical recession, remains.

Weekly FX Wrap: Lira lives on whilst Peso plumbs the depths, thank Trump
content:
DXY/CNH

Overall an upbeat week for the index, which is poised to end the EU session closer to the middle of a 97.54-98.30 weekly range after kick-starting the week at the bottom of the band. Trade rhetoric has soured further this week after President Trump noted that the US is not yet ready for a trade deal. Meanwhile, China reiterated its stance that it will have to take countermeasures if the US keeps pressing along. Furthermore, sources noted that Beijing has readied plans to restrict exports of rate earths to the US, whilst also constructing a blacklist of US tech names in retaliation to the Huawei ban. On the data front, the index was largely unscathed by this week’s tier 1 data (Q1 Core PCE marginally softer, expected GDP revision and in-line April PCE), potentially muted to an extent by the month-end rebalancing and the risk-off cloud over the market. Either way, the index is currently straddling on either side of 98.00 ahead of an action-packed week which includes the Fed’s Inflation conference and the US labour report. Meanwhile, the Yuan is set to post a week of losses, albeit more contained than some of the downside seen earlier in the month, with the May USD/CNH range at 6.72-947 thus far. Upside in the pair also coincided with former PBoC governor Zhou who stated that USD/CNH threshold does not necessarily stand at 7.00. USD/CNH is poised to end closer to the top of a 6.92-947 weekly range as participants eye the release of Caixin PMIs next week alongside trade developments.

 

AUD/NZD/CAD

All set to end the week lower vs. the Buck, albeit the Aussie less-so than its risk-currency peers, with UBS noting that the AUD has too much short priced in to be much affected to the downside in the short term unless the Australian stock market collapses. The Kiwi on the other hand, has had a relatively downbeat week and is set to end the EU session near enough to the bottom of its 0.6495-6560 range, initially dampened by bleak NZ business outlook before risk sentiment took the pair lower. Elsewhere, the Loonie eyes a weekly loss of around 0.8%, potentially mostly on the back of the collapse in crude prices over the week. This week also saw the BoC rate decision wherein the governing council viewed the late 2018 slowdown as temporary, however, the board also made no mention of returning to neutral range. Furthermore, the fallout between Mexico and the US saw some pressure on the CAD amid the possible ramifications this could have on the USMCA, although officials noted that the deal and the Mexican tariffs are two different issues. Finally, an overall mixed Canadian GDP report did little to sway the Loonie as external factors largely dominated the currency. USD/CAD saw (so far) a weekly range of 1.3440-3563. Back to the AUD, next week sees the release of the RBA rate decision, with markets expecting a 25bps cut to its Cash Rate, shortly followed by the Aussie Q1 GDP figures.

 

CHF/JPY

A mostly risk-off week has guided safe-haven inflow into the currencies, with USD/JPY set to end the EU week comfortably under 109.00, having fluctuated within a relatively wide weekly range of 109.92-107.72. Conversely, despite the risk-driven strength in the Franc by the end of the week, USD/CHF is poised to end the week in the red, with speculators highlighting potential SNB intervention amidst the high-risk environment. USD/CHF is set to end the session around the 1.005 mark, closer to the middle of the 1.001-010 range. 

 

EUR/GBP

The single currency and Sterling were largely dictated by USD action throughout most of the week, with little-to-no new news-flow on the Brexit front, whilst EUR shrugged off the weaker than forecast German inflation figures as RHS demand in EUR/GBP set the tone for the currencies at the end of the week. The cross is set for a fourth consecutive week of gains and poised to end the EU session nearer to the top of the weekly 0.8791-8874 range. Looking ahead, next week sees the release of the EZ CPI, followed by the ECB rate decision and full staff economic projections. 

 

EM

An eventful week for the EM currencies, with focus on the TRY and the MXN and their ties to the US. The Lira took the spotlight earlier in the week following a phone call between US President Trump and Turkish President Erdogan in which they agreed to meet on the side-lines of the June G20 meeting in Osaka after Turkey released a NASA scientist from its prison. The optimism from the call against USD/TRY to fall from levels over 6.1000 to a weekly low of 5.8215 (thus far). Elsewhere, the MXN hit levels last seen in Dec 2018 vs the Buck as US President Trump noted that a 5% tariff will be imposed on all goods coming from Mexico beginning June 10th until illegal immigrants coming through Mexico to the US stop, and tariff will gradually increase until illegal immigration problem is remedied. The Peso immediately saw downside and continued that trajectory throughout the session, with USD/MXN spiking higher from around 19.1500, through its 50 WMA (19.2766) and 200 DMA (19.3360) to a high of 19.8300.

content:
Bund yields have regained some composure after the trade-induced record low and were relatively reticent to react upon the CPI data which came in below the prior on a YY & MM basis, as was expected. Similar price action has also been noted in the UK 10yr benchmark, with both Bund and Gilt futures hanging just under the 130.00 and 168.50 handles respectively as opposed to the day’s high prints of 130.14 & 168.63. BTP futures have also seen some buying after the session nadir of 128.99 although remain in negative territory for the day by about 30 ticks, with traders looking out for the Italian EU reply over public finance concerns coming today.

In the US, the action remains in the longer end of the curve, with little by the way of a sustained reaction noted after the in-line Core PCE Price Index print and impressive Chicago PMI figure. This comes as trade remains largely dictated by tariff talk, as the Trump twitter tirade continues to draw focus ahead of comments from Bostic and Williams.

Talking Crude: Mexico tariff threats pushes prices even lower
content:
• The crude complex is suffering from a fresh bout of risk-off sentiment following US threats of tariffs on Mexico. Thursday’s downfall was more of a supply-driven move where the market was caught offside on the EIA inventory release, but no sooner did it have time to breath, where President Trump announced overnight that the US will be implementing tariffs on Mexico. Consequentially, there has been a flight to safety, with crude markets under pressure, where “Every single daily M/A, short, medium or long-term, contract and continuation, have been penetrated on the downside,” PVM’s analysts highlight.
  • A (slight) easing on the geopolitical/Iran front is also providing headwinds. Following original US sanctions on Iranian crude, the Treasury was due to implement new sanctions on Iran’s second largest export, Petrochemicals, in mid-May but is now delaying that decision due to the desire to deescalate tensions between Washington and Tehran. WSJ reported overnight that the Trump administration said that it would continue to let Iranian crude importers (e.g. China and India), who were previously granted sanction waivers, continue importing to the cap they had been granted; previously nations were likely to be hesitant of exporting to their caps due to the escalation of tensions between US and Iran. On more of a side note, Exxon (XOM) announced it will be returning personnel to Iraq, where it had previously evacuated due to risk of conflict in the region, signalling an ease of concerns; Iran is reported to be operating via proxies in Iraq.

US President Trump announced new tariffs on Mexico starting at 5%, before rising to 25%, which he said will remain unless and until Mexico significantly stops inflow of “illegal aliens” through its territory. RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 31st May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices are firmly in negative territory [Euro Stoxx 50 -1.7%] following US Presidents Trump’s plans to place tariffs on Mexican goods at an initial level of 4%
  • China’s Global Times Editor states that China will take major retaliatory measures against the US placing Huawei and other Chinese companies on an Entity List
  • In FX, the Mexican Peso underperforms while safe haven JPY benefits from the risk-off tone
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI (Prelim), US Core PCE Price Index, Personal Income, Chicago PMI & University of Michigan Sentiment, Fed's Williams & Bostic

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed heading into month-end with early pressure seen after US President Trump announced to place 5% tariffs on all goods from Mexico from June 10th, which will increase to as much as 25% by October 1st and remain there until Mexico addresses the illegal immigration inflows to the US through its territory. The announcement pressured US equity futures to give back the prior session’s gains in which the Emini S&P breached its 200DMA to the downside and the DJIA briefly slipped below the 25K level, with Wall St on track for its worst monthly performance YTD. ASX 200 (Unch.) was lower for most the session with tech and energy the underperformers although strength in gold and other mining names stemmed the downside in the index, while Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) suffered from currency flows and with automakers spooked by fears of a trigger-happy ‘Tariff Man’. Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were mixed as participants digested varied Chinese PMI data in which Manufacturing PMI fell short of estimates and slipped into contractionary territory but Non-Manufacturing PMI printed inline, and although the PBoC refrained from open market operations, its efforts this week resulted to a total net injection of CNY 430bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs followed suit to the upside in T-notes as Trump’s announcement spurred safe-haven demand, while the BoJ were also present in the market for JPY 680bln of JGBs in the belly to super long-end.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly injection of CNY 430bln vs. CNY 100bln net injection W/W. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8992 (Prev. 6.8990)

PBoC Deputy Governor says to keep liquidity ample via various monetary tools and will maintain low RRR for smaller banks. (Newswires)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (May) 49.4 vs. Exp. 49.9 (Prev. 50.1). (Newswires) Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (May) 54.3 vs. Exp. 54.3 (Prev. 54.3) Chinese Composite (May) 53.3 (Prev. 53.4)

China reportedly quietly adjusted tools for handling capital flows in which it increased the number of indicators and conditions for banks to consider to manage their risks. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor tweets that based on what he knows "China will take major retaliative measures against the US placing Huawei and other Chinese companies on Entity List. Beijing will not wait passively and more countermeasures will follow" (Twitter) Subsequently, Chinese Commerce Ministry says that they are to draft a list of 'unreliable' entities, targeting foreign players that harm the interest of Chinese firms. Prior to this, Synopsys, the world’s largest supplier of chip design tools have stopped providing software updates to Huawei and have placed new intellectual property sales to Huawei on hold., as according to Nikkei citing sources. (Newswires)

Bank of Korea kept its benchmark rate unchanged at 1.75% as expected, while the decision was not unanimous as board member Cho dissented and called for a cut. Furthermore, the BoK said exports are to gradually recover and consumption will continue to grow but added that trade risks have increased which contributes to uncertainties for Korea. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump announced a 5% tariff on all goods coming from Mexico beginning June 10th until illegal immigrants coming through Mexico to the US stop. Trump added the US will begin raising tariffs on Mexico beyond 5% on July 1st and will continue until it reaches 25% on October 1st, where they will remain unless and until Mexico significantly stops illegal inflow of aliens through its territory. (Newswires/Twitter)

Mexico Deputy Foreign Minister Seade said the tariffs would be disastrous and that Mexico would respond strongly if tariffs are carried out. Seade also commented that this was an unexpected move by Trump and is very extreme, while he added that the normal route would be to mirror the tariffs although that would lead to a trade war. (Newswires)

USTR Lightizer told congress they are submitting a draft statement of administrative action to implement USMCA deal, while US House Speaker Pelosi commented that the decision to expedite USMCA process is not a positive step. (Newswires)

UK/EU

ECB's Visco says that Italy's increase in 2019 debt-to-GDP ratio could exceed the forecast Govt. budget due to lower than expected privatization proceeds; says it is counter-productive to raise public deficit and risks triggering a restrictive expansion

Italian Finance Minister Tria is reportedly to tell the EU that Italian debt is sustainable and manageable., (Repubblica)

German Saxony State CPI YY (May) 1.4% (Prev. 1.9%)

- German Saxony State CPI MM (May) 0.3% (Prev. 0.9%)

GEOPOLITICAL

US has delayed tougher sanctions on Iran's petrochemical sectors in an attempt to dial back tensions, according to WSJ citing sources. (WSJ)

EQUITIES

European Indices trade firmly in negative territory this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 -1.7%] as sentiment took a hit as US President Trump revisited his ‘Tariff Man’ persona by announcing the placement of 5% tariffs on all goods stemming from Mexico as of June 10th; which may increase by up to an additional 20% by October 1st. Currently eight automakers including Volkswagen (-3.6%) and Fiat Chrysler (-4.6%) operate plants in Mexico, as such the Stoxx 600 Auto Sector (-2.8%) is significantly lagging its peers with the Dax (-1.6%) the underperforming bourse due to automakers/parts having around a 14% weighting in the Dax. Auto names aside, other companies with exposure to Mexico have been significantly affected by President Trump’s announcement with the likes of Tenaris (-4.7%) afflicted due to the Co. operating one of the world’s largest manufacturing centres for steel tubes in Mexico. Elsewhere, Italian banks are at their lowest level since November 2016 due to the ongoing internal political tensions as well as the potential for Italy to face EU disciplinary procedures in the form of a EUR 3.5bln fine. Other notable movers this morning include Wirecard (-11.3%) who are lagging the Stoxx 600 after reports that several public prosecutors are said to see the Co. as the central payment processor for the fraudulent trading site Option888. Bucking the risk-off sentiment and at the other end of the Stoxx 600 are Whitbread (+1.9%) after the Co’s board decided that the second phase in their three phase capital programme is a GBP 2bln tender offer.

Of note for US equities Ford (F) and General Motors (GM) have auto plants in the US and the Co’s are currently down by around -3.35 and -5.1% respectively in the pre-market.

FX

DXY - The broad Dollar and Index are on the backfoot this morning with DXY now back below 98.000, albeit marginally. The Buck awaits key US data in the form of April PCE prices as traders look for any clues if the “dip in inflation was transitory” as the Fed stated at its most recent meeting. On a technical front, to the downside DXY sees its 50 DMA just under the 97.50 level at 97.47 ahead of clean air down to 97.00.

MXN, CAD - The clear underperformers today, more-so the Peso after President Trump dampened USMCA hopes by taking aim at Mexico. The Peso immediately saw downside and continued that trajectory throughout the session, with USD/MXN spiking higher from around 19.1500, through its 50 WMA (19.2766) and 200 DMA (19.3360) to a high of 19.7360. Meanwhile, from Canada’s side, the potential ramifications on the USMCA deal, coupled with lower energy prices sent USD/CAD higher to around 1.3550 from a low of around 1.3494 ahead of a barrage of Canadian data including Q1 GDP.

JPY, CHF - The Yen stands as the clear G10 outperformer this morning amid the overall risk aversion in the market with downside vs. the USD exacerbated as Trump spills his trade war into Mexico. USD/JPY cleanly broke below the 109.00 figure and continues to lose ground below the level, having traded within a wide 109.62-108.76 band, with buyers reported at 108.75 ahead of the Jan 28 low just above 108.50. Following the latest developments, Morgan Stanley believes that a breach below 109.00 support opens downside potential to 107.70. Meanwhile, the Swiss Franc also posts gains, albeit to a lesser extent, with traders speculating potential SNB intervention to keep the CHF strengthening further. USD/CHF currently rests just above the 1.0050 mark ahead of its 100 DMA at 1.0037.

EM - The EM space is weaker across the board amidst the Trump-sparked collapse in the Mexican Peso, albeit the TRY has shown some resilience as it consolidates following yesterday’s stellar performance. However, geopolitical risks for the Lira remain as the Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesperson has dismissed reports that the Russian S-400 delivery will be delayed, which comes after US pressured the country to dump the USD 2.5bln deal with Russia, which contradicted prior reports that the Russian system will be delivered ahead of scheduled. Either way, markets are looking at any potential US sanctions on Turkey if the delivery does go through, which Turkey noted was "a done deal"

AUD, NZD, EUR, GBP - All marginally firmer against the Greenback (ex-GBP), albeit more due to a pullback in the USD than individual factors. The Antipodeans were little fazed by the overnight miss in the Chinese NBS manufacturing PMI as currencies await the Caixin release next week alongside the RBA’s “live” rate decision and Aussie GDP. Elsewhere, the expectations for a post-Easter collapse sees the EUR largely shrugging off the downticks in German state inflation numbers, as markets gear up for the national release at 1300BST. EUR/USD resides closer to the top of today’s 1.1126-54 band with resistance reported at 1.1155 ahead of 1.1170. Meanwhile, the Pound has lost some ground in recent trade, particularly vs the EUR with some citing RHS demand and EUR/GBP bids at 0.8850 as factors.

Indian government are likely to announce a "big bang" economic reform package in the first 100 days of the new Modi government, according to a government think tank official. (Newswires)

Turkish Central Bank will continue to use all available instruments to effectively achieve price stability, and to support financial stability. (Newswires)

S&P upgraded Indonesia's sovereign rating to "BBB" from "BBB-"; outlook stable. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Bund yields continued their regression and have once again set a new record low of -0.206%, whilst UK 10yr Gilt yields have followed suit and hit 2016 lows of 0.861% after more trade sabre rattling reverberated around markets, including a tariff double down comment from VP Pence and Hu Xijin suggesting China are to take “major” retaliative measures. This coupled with the contractionary Manufacturing PMI from China has seen the majority of fixed income futures and the risk-off mood pick up steam ahead of the release of German CPI, which based on the state releases thus far is likely to see a moderation on both a YY and MM basis. Italian debt is bucking the bucking the higher price trend, however, and underperform their counterparts (10yr -80 ticks) after comments suggested their Finance Minister is to tell the EU that all is well with Italian debt, despite suggestions it is unsustainable, with the domestic CPI print failing to offer support to the Italian economic woes.

Turning stateside, futures are higher across the curve, with the majority of the action in the longer end as the aforementioned Chinese tensions have been coupled with additional North American tension after the President announced a 5% tariff on Mexican goods as of June 10th until illegal immigrants coming through Mexico to the US stop. This has seen 10yr yields slip to sub-Sept. 2017 nadirs of 2.168%, with the August 2017 2.124% low eyed up next on the downside should more bearish impulses be struck by Bostic and Williams later in the day after the release of Core PCE. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities are mixed with the energy markets plumbing the depths as risk sentiment further deteriorates amid trade war escalations coupled with rising US crude production. WTI (-2.1%) straddles around the USD 55/bbl level, having already dipped below the figure whilst its Brent (-2.5%) counterpart follows the same trajectory as it hovers around USD 64.50/bbl. Furthermore, some geopolitical risk premium may have also unwound in the oils amid reports that US has delayed tougher sanctions Iran's petrochemical sectors in an attempt to dial back tensions. Elsewhere, gold (+0.6%) benefits from the risk aversion and the receding USD as it creeps closer to the USD 1300/oz level, whilst copper extends its decline below the USD 2.600/lb level amid the soured risk tone coupled with disappointing Chinese PMI data.

OPEC oil output in May declined 60K bpd from April to 30.17mln bpd which was the lowest since 2015, while compliance to supply cut deal was at 96% vs. Prev. 132% M/M, according to a Reuters survey.  (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said attacks on oil tankers in the Gulf was an effort by Iranians to raise global crude prices, while the US Special Envoy for Iran Hook said any countries purchasing Iranian crude oil after expiration of waivers will be subject to sanctions. Subsequently, the Iranian Foreign Ministry has rejected the "baseless" accusations by Saudi Arabia that Iran attacked Saudi tankers and targeted pipelines, Iran added that Saudi has joined US and Israel to mobilise opinion against Tehran. (Newswires)

subject: Nomura Quant: US bonds in melt-up mode, risk of CTAs returning to selling stocks
content:
• Stock market sentiment, both in the US and globally, is still near the neutral line, according to Nomura’s composite gauge. In the absence of any truly game-changing good news, Nomura think it is too soon to make the call that sentiment has started to improve again.
  • Elsewhere, see a risk that CTAs' present momentum will carry them into a net short position in S&P 500 futures. CTAs could return to selling stocks specifically to attack downside if upcoming data points disappoint.
  • Furthermore, once they have started going short, CTAs have historically tended to more or less uniformly add shorts for seven consecutive trading days. At that point, CTAs' technically driven stock selling has tended to run out of steam unless other market players join in the selling. 
  • Risk-parity funds, seem to have unloaded commodities in favor of buying more investment-grade bonds (including USTs) as part of their end-of-month portfolio rebalancing.  
  • CTAs are leveraging up as they chase the upside momentum in UST futures; their net buying has picked up across all tenors. To all appearances, the US bond market is experiencing a mechanical melt-up. 
  • CTAs and risk-parity funds have been selling commodities. CTAs have also swung to shorting WTI crude oil futures, and are digging ever deeper in shorting COMEX copper futures as well.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

31th May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed heading into month-end with early pressure seen after US President Trump announced to place 5% tariffs on all goods from Mexico from June 10th, which will increase to as much as 25% by October 1st and remain there until Mexico addresses the illegal immigration inflows to the US through its territory. The announcement pressured US equity futures to give back the prior session’s gains in which the E-Mini S&P breached its 200DMA to the downside and the DJIA briefly slipped below the 25K level, with Wall St on track for its worst monthly performance YTD. ASX 200 (Unch.) was lower for most the session with tech and energy the underperformers although strength in gold and other mining names stemmed the downside in the index, while Nikkei 225 (-1.0%) suffered from currency flows and with automakers spooked by fears of a trigger-happy ‘Tariff Man’. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were mixed as participants digested varied Chinese PMI data in which Manufacturing PMI fell short of estimates and slipped into contraction territory but Non-Manufacturing PMI printed inline, and although the PBoC refrained from open market operations, its efforts this week resulted to a total net injection of CNY 430bln.

FTSE

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – US law firms Levi & Korsinsky and Pomerantz, have announced they are launching an investigation into the Co. following an accounting error made early on in 2019. (Times)

Oil names –WTI crude futures extended on recent losses to test the USD 56.00/bbl level to the downside after having slipped around 6% from Thursday’s peak amid a bearish EIA inventory report

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 31st May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices are subdued with sentiment weighed on by US President Trump’s plans to place tariffs on Mexican goods at an initial level of 5%
  • Chinese Manufacturing PMI moved into contractionary territory and printed below the estimate at 49.4
  • China reportedly has plans to limit rare earth sales to the US if necessary, while US VP Pence says Trump and Xi will likely meet at the G20 summit
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Retail Sales & CPI (Prelim), Italian GDP (Final) & CPI (Prelim), US Core PCE Price Index, Personal Income, Chicago PMI & University of Michigan Sentiment, ECB's Visco, Fed's Williams & Bostic

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed heading into month-end with early pressure seen after US President Trump announced to place 5% tariffs on all goods from Mexico from June 10th, which will increase to as much as 25% by October 1st and remain there until Mexico addresses the illegal immigration inflows to the US through its territory. The announcement pressured US equity futures to give back the prior session’s gains in which the Emini S&P breached its 200DMA to the downside and the DJIA briefly slipped below the 25K level, with Wall St on track for its worst monthly performance YTD. ASX 200 (Unch.) was lower for most the session with tech and energy the underperformers although strength in gold and other mining names stemmed the downside in the index, while Nikkei 225 (-1.0%) suffered from currency flows and with automakers spooked by fears of a trigger-happy ‘Tariff Man’. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were mixed as participants digested varied Chinese PMI data in which Manufacturing PMI fell short of estimates and slipped into contractionary territory but Non-Manufacturing PMI printed inline, and although the PBoC refrained from open market operations, its efforts this week resulted to a total net injection of CNY 430bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs followed suit to the upside in T-notes as Trump’s announcement spurred safe-haven demand, while the BoJ were also present in the market for JPY 680bln of JGBs in the belly to super long-end.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly injection of CNY 430bln vs. CNY 100bln net injection W/W. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8992 (Prev. 6.8990)

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (May) 49.4 vs. Exp. 49.9 (Prev. 50.1). (Newswires) Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (May) 54.3 vs. Exp. 54.3 (Prev. 54.3) Chinese Composite (May) 53.3 (Prev. 53.4)

US Vice President Pence said the US can more than double tariffs on China if necessary and hopes progress can be made at the G20 but added that China must agree to make reforms. Pence also commented that President Trump will probably meet with Xi at the G20 and will urge him to release the Canadian detainees, while he stated the US sees Huawei as incompatible with its security needs and is working to promote alternatives. (Newswires)

China reportedly has a plan ready to limit rare earth sales to the US if needed, while there were separate reports that Huawei ordered employees to cancel meetings with US contacts and repatriated American workers at its Shenzhen HQ. (Newswires/FT)

China reportedly quietly adjusted tools for handling capital flows in which it increased the number of indicators and conditions for banks to consider to manage their risks. (Newswires)

Bank of Korea kept its benchmark rate unchanged at 1.75% as expected, while the decision was not unanimous as board member Cho dissented and called for a cut. Furthermore, the BoK said exports are to gradually recover and consumption will continue to grow but added that trade risks have increased which contributes to uncertainties for Korea. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK GfK Consumer Confidence (May) -10 vs. Exp. -12.0 (Prev. -13.0) UK Lloyds Business Barometer (May) 10 (Prev. 14)

Italy’s 5 Star Movement members voted in favour of Deputy PM Di Maio to continue as leader who won 80% of the votes in the internal ballot. (Newswires)

FX

 

DXY was steady above the 98.00 level as its major counterparts EUR/USD and GBP/USD languished near this week’s lows at the weaker end of the 1.1100 and 1.2600 handles respectively, while Citi's month-end FX hedge rebalancing model also suggested moderate buying of USD. Elsewhere, Trump’s tariff announcement on Mexico spurred flows in into safe-haven JPY and saw USD/JPY test the 109.00 level, while MXN dropped nearly 2% and was the biggest fallout from the tariff threat which Deputy Foreign Minister Seade described as very extreme and suggested that the normal route would be to mirror the tariffs although that would lead to a trade war. CAD also weakened due to the potential ramifications on the USMCA, while antipodeans were flat as support at 0.6900 for AUD/USD and 0.6500 for NZD/USD helped prices rebound from the early tariff-related pressure.

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures extended on recent losses to test the USD 56.00/bbl level to the downside after having slipped around 6% from Thursday’s peak amid a bearish EIA inventory report. Gold continued on its ascent towards the USD 1300/oz level after the downward revisions to US GDP and Core PCE data, while copper was rangebound as it mirrored the indecisive tone in China.

OPEC oil output in May declined 60K bpd from April to 30.17mln bpd which was the lowest since 2015, while compliance to supply cut deal was at 96% vs. Prev. 132% M/M, according to a Reuters survey.  (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said attacks on oil tankers in the Gulf was an effort by Iranians to raise global crude prices, while the US Special Envoy for Iran Hook said any countries purchasing Iranian crude oil after expiration of waivers will be subject to sanctions. (Newswires)

US

Treasuries began Thursday on the backfoot, trading lower in the Asian and European session, before reversing course to settle approximately unchanged. A risk off US session helped spur bids in the T-plex, with the usual US-China trade talk deterioration dampening sentiment. The curve saw bull flattening on the day, with 30-year yields hitting 21-month lows, in addition to the 5-year yield testing the 2% handle. US T-note futures (M9) settled 2 ticks higher at 125-22.

US President Trump announced a 5% tariff on all goods coming from Mexico beginning June 10th until illegal immigrants coming through Mexico to the US stop. Trump added the US will begin raising tariffs on Mexico beyond 5% on July 1st and will continue until it reaches 25% on October 1st, where they will remain unless and until Mexico significantly stops illegal inflow of aliens through its territory. (Newswires/Twitter)

Mexico Deputy Foreign Minister Seade said the tariffs would be disastrous and that Mexico would respond strongly if tariffs are carried out. Seade also commented that this was an unexpected move by Trump and is very extreme, while he added that the normal route would be to mirror the tariffs although that would lead to a trade war. (Newswires)

USTR Lightizer told congress they are submitting a draft statement of administrative action to implement USMCA deal, while US House Speaker Pelosi commented that the decision to expedite USMCA process is not a positive step. (Newswires)

Fed's Clarida (Voter, Neutral) said the US economy is in a good place and the Fed are close to achieving the dual mandate. Clarida added that if inflation shortfall becomes persistent, the Fed would take that into account and is prepared to adjust balance sheet normalisation if conditions warrant, while he also commented that the Fed would be open to cutting rates if data suggests risks of a sharper than anticipated slowdown. (Newswires)

Fed's Quarles (Voter, Hawk) said financial stability risks must be incorporated into monetary policy decision making, while he added that current financial stability risks are not elevated and that accommodative policy can increase financial stability risks. (Newswires)
